USD.name: US Dollar
facts: The US Dollar is the most widely used currency in the world and the world's primary reserve currency..
The US Dollar is often referred to as the 'Greenback'.
The symbol '$' is derived from the Spanish Peso, which was widely used in the Americas.
The US Dollar is the official currency of 11 countries.

CAD.name: Canadian Dollar
facts: The Canadian Dollar is nicknamed the 'Loonie' due to the loon bird on the $1 coin.
Canada was the first country to use polymer banknotes.
The $1 and $2 bills were replaced by coins in 1987 and 1996, respectively.
Canada's banknotes feature tactile marks for the visually impaired.
The Canadian Dollar is often used as a benchmark for oil prices.

EUR.name: Euro
facts: The Euro is used by 20 of the 27 European Union countries.
The Euro banknotes are identical across all member countries.
Each Euro coin has a common side and a country-specific side.
The Euro is the second most traded currency in the world.
The €500 note was discontinued in 2019 to combat illegal activities.

AED.name: United Arab Emirates Dirham
facts: The UAE Dirham was introduced in 1973, replacing the Qatar and Dubai Riyal.
The word 'Dirham' comes from the Greek word 'Drachma'.
Coins in the UAE feature traditional symbols like coffee pots and gazelles.
The AED is pegged to the US Dollar at a fixed rate.
The UAE Dirham is used in all seven emirates of the UAE.

AFN.name: Afghan Afghani
facts: The Afghan Afghani was introduced in 1925, replacing the Afghan rupee.
The symbol '؋' is unique to the Afghan Afghani.
Afghanistan issued its first polymer banknotes in 2004.
The Afghani is subdivided into 100 puls.
The Afghan Central Bank is responsible for issuing and regulating the Afghani.

ALL.name: Albanian Lek
facts: The Albanian Lek was introduced in 1926.
The name 'Lek' is derived from Alexander the Great's name.
Lek coins feature images of Albania's national heroes.
The Lek is subdivided into 100 qindarka.
The Lek is used only in Albania and is not traded internationally.

AMD.name: Armenian Dram
facts: The Armenian Dram was introduced in 1993 after the fall of the Soviet Union.
The word 'Dram' means 'money' in Armenian.
Armenian banknotes feature cultural and historical figures.
The Dram is subdivided into 100 luma.
The Armenian Central Bank is responsible for issuing the Dram.

ARS.name: Argentine Peso
facts: The Argentine Peso was introduced in 1992.
The symbol '$' is shared with the US Dollar.
Banknotes feature images of Argentina's national heroes.
Argentina's 1,000 Peso note features a bird called the Rufous Hornero, the national bird of Argentina.
The Argentine Peso has undergone several redenominations due to inflation.

AUD.name: Australian Dollar
facts: Australia was the first country to introduce polymer banknotes in 1988.
The $2 coin is smaller than the $1 coin.
The Australian Dollar is nicknamed the 'Aussie'.
The Australian $50 note features Edith Cowan, the first woman elected to an Australian parliament.
The Australian Dollar is one of the top 5 most traded currencies in the world.

AZN.name: Azerbaijani Manat
facts: The Azerbaijani Manat was reintroduced in 2006 after redenomination.
The word 'Manat' is derived from the Latin word 'Moneta'.
Azerbaijan's banknotes feature cultural and historical themes.
The Manat is subdivided into 100 qepik.
The Azerbaijani Manat is one of the most stable currencies in the region.

BAM.name: Bosnia-Herzegovina Convertible Mark
facts: The Bosnia-Herzegovina Convertible Mark is pegged to the Euro.
The currency's name comes from the German Mark, which it replaced.
Banknotes feature images of famous Bosnian landmarks.
The Convertible Mark is abbreviated as 'KM' in Bosnian.
Coins are issued in denominations of 5, 10, 20, and 50 fenings.

BDT.name: Bangladeshi Taka
facts: The Bangladeshi Taka was introduced in 1972 after independence.
The word 'Taka' means 'money' in Bengali.
Bangladesh was one of the first countries to issue polymer banknotes.
The Taka is subdivided into 100 poisha.
Bangladeshi banknotes feature images of national monuments and leaders.

BGN.name: Bulgarian Lev
facts: The Bulgarian Lev is pegged to the Euro at a fixed rate.
The word 'Lev' means 'lion' in Bulgarian.
Bulgarian banknotes feature famous cultural and historical figures.
The Lev is subdivided into 100 stotinki.
Bulgaria plans to adopt the Euro in the future.

BHD.name: Bahraini Dinar
facts: The Bahraini Dinar is one of the highest-valued currencies in the world.
The Dinar is subdivided into 1,000 fils.
Bahrain introduced its currency in 1965, replacing the Gulf Rupee.
Coins feature traditional Bahraini symbols like palm trees and dhows.
The Bahraini Dinar is pegged to the US Dollar.

BIF.name: Burundian Franc
facts: The Burundian Franc was introduced in 1964, replacing the Belgian Congo Franc.
The Franc is subdivided into 100 centimes, though centime coins are no longer used.
Burundi's banknotes feature images of local wildlife and cultural symbols.
The Franc is abbreviated as 'FBu' in Burundi.
Coins are rarely used in everyday transactions in Burundi.

BND.name: Brunei Dollar
facts: The Brunei Dollar is interchangeable with the Singapore Dollar at par.
Brunei's banknotes feature images of the Sultan and national landmarks.
The currency is abbreviated as 'B$' locally.
The Brunei Dollar was introduced in 1967, replacing the Malaya and British Borneo Dollar.
Brunei issues polymer banknotes for durability.

BOB.name: Bolivian Boliviano
facts: The Bolivian Boliviano was introduced in 1987, replacing the Peso Boliviano.
The currency is named after Simón Bolívar, a South American independence leader.
The Boliviano is subdivided into 100 centavos.
Bolivian banknotes feature images of national heroes and landmarks.
Coins are issued in denominations of 10, 20, and 50 centavos, and 1, 2, and 5 Bolivianos.

BRL.name: Brazilian Real
facts: The Brazilian Real was introduced in 1994 as part of an economic stabilization plan.
The word 'Real' means 'royal' in Portuguese.
Brazilian banknotes feature images of wildlife and cultural symbols.
The Real is subdivided into 100 centavos.
Brazil's banknotes are printed with tactile features for the visually impaired.

BWP.name: Botswanan Pula
facts: The Botswanan Pula was introduced in 1976, replacing the South African Rand.
The word 'Pula' means 'rain' in Setswana, symbolizing its value.
The Pula is subdivided into 100 thebe, which means 'shield' in Setswana.
Botswana's banknotes feature images of local wildlife and leaders.
The Pula is one of the strongest currencies in Africa.

BYN.name: Belarusian Ruble
facts: The Belarusian Ruble was redenominated in 2016, removing four zeros.
The Ruble is subdivided into 100 kopecks.
Belarusian banknotes feature images of architectural landmarks.
Coins were introduced in Belarus for the first time in 2016.
The Ruble is abbreviated as 'Br' in Belarus.

BZD.name: Belize Dollar
facts: The Belize Dollar is pegged to the US Dollar at a fixed rate of 2:1.
Belize's banknotes feature images of Queen Elizabeth II.
The currency is abbreviated as 'BZ$' locally.
The Belize Dollar was introduced in 1973, replacing the British Honduras Dollar.
Coins are issued in denominations of 1, 5, 10, 25, and 50 cents, and 1 Dollar.

CDF.name: Congolese Franc
facts: The Congolese Franc was introduced in 1997, replacing the Zaire.
The Franc is subdivided into 100 centimes.
Congolese banknotes feature images of local wildlife and cultural symbols.
Coins are rarely used in everyday transactions in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
The Franc is abbreviated as 'CDF' internationally.

CHF.name: Swiss Franc
facts: The Swiss Franc is the only Franc still issued in Europe.
Swiss banknotes feature images of cultural and scientific achievements.
The Franc is subdivided into 100 centimes.
Switzerland issues some of the most secure banknotes in the world.
The Swiss Franc is considered a safe-haven currency.

CLP.name: Chilean Peso
facts: The Chilean Peso was introduced in 1975, replacing the Escudo.
The Peso is subdivided into 100 centavos, though centavo coins are no longer used.
Chilean banknotes feature images of national heroes and landmarks.
The currency is abbreviated as 'CLP' internationally.
Coins are issued in denominations of 1, 5, 10, 50, 100, and 500 Pesos.

CNY.name: Chinese Yuan
facts: The Chinese Yuan is also known as 'Renminbi', meaning 'people's currency'.
The Yuan is subdivided into 10 jiao and 100 fen.
Chinese banknotes feature images of Mao Zedong and cultural landmarks.
The Yuan is abbreviated as 'CNY' internationally.
China issues polymer banknotes for higher denominations.

COP.name: Colombian Peso
facts: The Colombian Peso was introduced in 1810, replacing the Real.
The Peso is subdivided into 100 centavos.
Colombian banknotes feature images of national heroes and cultural symbols.
The currency is abbreviated as 'COP' internationally.
Coins are issued in denominations of 50, 100, 200, 500, and 1,000 Pesos.

CRC.name: Costa Rican Colón
facts: The Costa Rican Colón is named after Christopher Columbus (Cristóbal Colón in Spanish).
The Colón is subdivided into 100 céntimos.
Costa Rican banknotes feature images of the country's biodiversity, including sloths and sharks.
The Colón was introduced in 1896, replacing the Costa Rican Peso.
Coins are issued in denominations ranging from 5 to 500 Colones.

CVE.name: Cape Verdean Escudo
facts: The Cape Verdean Escudo is pegged to the Euro at a fixed rate.
The Escudo is subdivided into 100 centavos.
Cape Verdean coins feature images of local flora and fauna.
The currency is abbreviated as 'CVE' internationally.
The Escudo was introduced in 1914, replacing the Portuguese Real.

CZK.name: Czech Republic Koruna
facts: The Czech Koruna was introduced in 1993 after the split of Czechoslovakia.
The word 'Koruna' means 'crown' in Czech.
Czech banknotes feature famous historical figures like Charles IV and composer Bedřich Smetana.
The Koruna is subdivided into 100 haléřů, though haléř coins are no longer used.
The Czech Republic has not adopted the Euro despite being an EU member.

DJF.name: Djiboutian Franc
facts: The Djiboutian Franc is pegged to the US Dollar at a fixed rate.
The Franc is subdivided into 100 centimes, though centime coins are rarely used.
Djiboutian banknotes feature images of local wildlife and cultural symbols.
The currency is abbreviated as 'DJF' internationally.
Coins are issued in denominations of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, 50, and 100 Francs.

DKK.name: Danish Krone
facts: The Danish Krone is pegged to the Euro through the ERM II mechanism.
The word 'Krone' means 'crown' in Danish.
Danish banknotes feature bridges and prehistoric artifacts.
The Krone is subdivided into 100 øre, though øre coins are no longer used.
Denmark has opted out of adopting the Euro despite being an EU member.

DOP.name: Dominican Peso
facts: The Dominican Peso was introduced in 1844 after the country's independence.
The Peso is subdivided into 100 centavos.
Dominican banknotes feature images of national heroes and landmarks.
The currency is abbreviated as 'DOP' internationally.
Coins are issued in denominations of 1, 5, 10, and 25 Pesos.

DZD.name: Algerian Dinar
facts: The Algerian Dinar was introduced in 1964, replacing the Algerian Franc.
The Dinar is subdivided into 100 centimes.
Algerian banknotes feature images of historical and cultural landmarks.
The currency is abbreviated as 'DZD' internationally.
Coins are issued in denominations of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, 50, and 100 Dinars.

EGP.name: Egyptian Pound
facts: The Egyptian Pound is abbreviated as 'LE', which stands for 'Livre Égyptienne'.
The Pound is subdivided into 100 piastres.
Egyptian banknotes feature images of ancient monuments like the Sphinx and temples.
Coins are issued in denominations of 25 and 50 piastres, and 1 Pound.
The Egyptian Pound is one of the oldest currencies still in use.

ERN.name: Eritrean Nakfa
facts: The Eritrean Nakfa was introduced in 1997, replacing the Ethiopian Birr.
The Nakfa is named after the town of Nakfa, a symbol of Eritrean resistance.
The Nakfa is subdivided into 100 cents.
Eritrean banknotes feature images of cultural and historical significance.
Coins are issued in denominations of 1, 5, 10, 25, and 50 cents, and 1 Nakfa.

ETH.name: Ethereum
facts: Ethereum introduced the concept of smart contracts, revolutionizing blockchain technology.
It is the second-largest cryptocurrency by market capitalization after Bitcoin.
Ether (ETH), the native cryptocurrency of Ethereum, is used to pay for transactions and computational services on the network.
Ethereum's co-founder, Vitalik Buterin, was only 19 years old when he proposed the platform.
The Ethereum network transitioned to a proof-of-stake consensus mechanism in 2022, significantly reducing its energy consumption.

ETB.name: Ethiopian Birr
facts: The Ethiopian Birr is one of the oldest currencies in Africa.
The Birr is subdivided into 100 santim.
Ethiopian banknotes feature images of national landmarks and leaders.
The currency is abbreviated as 'ETB' internationally.
Coins are issued in denominations of 1, 5, 10, 25, and 50 santim, and 1 Birr.

GBP.name: British Pound Sterling
facts: The British Pound Sterling is the oldest currency still in use.
The Pound is often referred to as 'Quid' in informal contexts.
British banknotes feature images of Queen Elizabeth II and historical figures.
The Pound is subdivided into 100 pence.
The £1 coin was redesigned in 2017 to include advanced security features.

GEL.name: Georgian Lari
facts: The Georgian Lari was introduced in 1995, replacing the Georgian Coupon.
The word 'Lari' means 'treasure' in Georgian.
Georgian banknotes feature images of cultural and historical figures.
The Lari is subdivided into 100 tetri.
Coins are issued in denominations of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, and 50 tetri, and 1 and 2 Lari.

GHS.name: Ghanaian Cedi
facts: The Ghanaian Cedi was introduced in 2007 after redenomination.
The word 'Cedi' is derived from 'sedie', a local word for cowry shells, which were once used as currency.
The Cedi is subdivided into 100 pesewas.
Ghanaian banknotes feature images of the 'Big Six', leaders of Ghana's independence movement.
Coins are issued in denominations of 1, 5, 10, 20, and 50 pesewas, and 1 Cedi.

INR.name: Indian Rupee
facts: The Indian Rupee symbol (₹) was introduced in 2010.
The word 'Rupee' is derived from the Sanskrit word 'Rupya', meaning silver.
Mahatma Gandhi's portrait has been featured on all Indian banknotes since 1996.

IQD.name: Iraqi Dinar
facts: The Iraqi Dinar was introduced in 1932, replacing the Indian Rupee.
The Dinar is subdivided into 1,000 fils, though fils coins are no longer used.
Iraqi banknotes feature images of historical and cultural landmarks.

IRR.name: Iranian Rial
facts: The Iranian Rial was introduced in 1932, replacing the Qiran.
The Rial is subdivided into 100 dinars, though dinar coins are no longer used.
Iranian banknotes feature images of cultural and religious landmarks.

ISK.name: Icelandic Króna
facts: The Icelandic Króna was introduced in 1922, replacing the Danish Krone.
The word 'Króna' means 'crown' in Icelandic.
Icelandic banknotes feature images of historical figures and cultural symbols.

JMD.name: Jamaican Dollar
facts: The Jamaican Dollar was introduced in 1969, replacing the Jamaican Pound.
The $1 coin features the national hero Marcus Garvey.
Jamaican banknotes feature images of national heroes and landmarks.

JOD.name: Jordanian Dinar
facts: The Jordanian Dinar was introduced in 1950, replacing the Palestinian Pound.
The Dinar is subdivided into 1,000 fils.
Jordanian banknotes feature images of historical and cultural landmarks.

JPY.name: Japanese Yen
facts: The Japanese Yen is the third most traded currency in the world.
The Yen is subdivided into 100 sen, though sen coins are no longer used.
Japanese banknotes feature images of cultural and historical figures.

KES.name: Kenyan Shilling
facts: The Kenyan Shilling was introduced in 1966, replacing the East African Shilling.
The Shilling is subdivided into 100 cents.
Kenyan banknotes feature images of national heroes and landmarks.

KMF.name: Comorian Franc
facts: The Comorian Franc is pegged to the Euro at a fixed rate.
The Franc is subdivided into 100 centimes, though centime coins are rarely used.
Comorian banknotes feature images of local flora and fauna.

KHR.name: Cambodian Riel
facts: The Cambodian Riel was introduced in 1953, replacing the French Indochinese Piastre.
The Riel is subdivided into 100 sen.
Cambodian banknotes feature images of cultural and historical landmarks.

KZT.name: Kazakhstani Tenge
facts: The Kazakhstani Tenge was introduced in 1993, replacing the Soviet Ruble.
The Tenge is subdivided into 100 tiyn.
Kazakhstani banknotes feature images of cultural and historical landmarks.

KRW.name: South Korean Won
facts: The South Korean Won was introduced in 1945, replacing the Korean Yen.
The Won is subdivided into 100 jeon, though jeon coins are rarely used.
South Korean banknotes feature images of historical figures and cultural landmarks.

KWD.name: Kuwaiti Dinar
facts: The Kuwaiti Dinar is one of the highest-valued currencies in the world.
The Dinar is subdivided into 1,000 fils.
Kuwaiti banknotes feature images of cultural and historical landmarks.

LBP.name: Lebanese Pound
facts: The Lebanese Pound was introduced in 1924, replacing the Ottoman Lira.
The Pound is subdivided into 100 piastres, though piastre coins are rarely used.
Lebanese banknotes feature images of cultural and historical landmarks.

LKR.name: Sri Lankan Rupee
facts: The Sri Lankan Rupee was introduced in 1872, replacing the Indian Rupee.
The Rupee is subdivided into 100 cents.
Sri Lankan banknotes feature images of cultural and historical landmarks.

LYD.name: Libyan Dinar
facts: The Libyan Dinar was introduced in 1971, replacing the Libyan Pound.
The Dinar is subdivided into 1,000 dirhams.
Libyan banknotes feature images of cultural and historical landmarks.

AOA.name: Angolan Kwanza
facts: The Angolan Kwanza was introduced in 1977, replacing the Escudo.
The Kwanza is subdivided into 100 cêntimos.
Angolan banknotes feature images of national heroes and landmarks.

BMD.name: Bermudan Dollar
facts: The Bermudan Dollar is pegged to the US Dollar at a 1:1 ratio.
Bermuda's banknotes feature images of local wildlife and landmarks.
The Bermudan Dollar was introduced in 1970, replacing the Bermudian Pound.

CUR.name: Placeholder Currency
facts: This is a placeholder currency used for selection purposes.
It does not represent any real-world currency.
It is used in examples and documentation to illustrate currency formats.
